instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P1V05S0_EN: What is P1V05S0_EN? P1V05S0_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V05_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P1V5S0_EN: What is P1V5S0_EN? P1V5S0_EN is an enable signal that turns on the PP1V5_S0 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message:
This board I received had liquid damage and after replacing some components and ultrasonicing the board it would power cycle, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> would pulse for one second on startup and there was no <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>/0 voltages.
I had to search around for a long time and ended up seeing that L4605 and <CAPACITOR>C4695</CAPACITOR> were not looking great so I replaced them and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> came back.
Pin 4 is now present on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> but there is no voltage on Pin 5(PGood)

I ended up seeing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> was missing and when I went to <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> I saw it was only hanging on to Pin 2 as if it was knocked away from Pin 1(not sure how that happened). I pulled <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> completely off the board, plugged in the charger and measured Pin 1 where it showed 3.3v and Pin 2 was around 1.3v. I put another resistor on there and Pin 1 and 2 would both measure 0v and there was no short to ground in diode mode.
I removed <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> again and measured and again the pad on Pin1 measured 3.3v and when I put another resistor on there it went back to 0v on both sides.
I replaced <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> thinking that was the issue but still there is no voltage on <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR>.

The resistance of <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> is 100ohms.
Diode Mode of <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> is around 0.47v and Pin 1 of <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> is around 0.52v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message:
There must be something short circuiting once power is applied on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>

It can't be <SIGNAL>P1V5S0_EN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>P1V05S0_EN</SIGNAL>, or <CAPACITOR>C8188</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C8187</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C8186</CAPACITOR> because they are all after other resistors. So cross those out.

Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> connects directly to <CHIP>U3310</CHIP> which is for thunderbolt. That's the only likely cause.

You said L4605 and <CAPACITOR>C4695</CAPACITOR> were corroded. They are right next to <CHIP>U3310</CHIP> which means <CHIP>U3310</CHIP> was likely hit by liquid as well. <CHIP>U3310</CHIP> is the only component that could be shorting your <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> to ground, AND it likely got wet.  Remove it and see what happens.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3310</CHIP> didnt look like it had any liquid damage to it. I removed it and still made no difference and I also removed <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> but that didnt solve anything either.
<RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> isn't showing as shorted to ground in diode mode.

Diode Mode: Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R8178</RESISTOR> is around 0.47v and Pin 2 is around 0.53v
<CAPACITOR>C8186</CAPACITOR>-88 all look fine visually and aren't shorted to ground.

What else do you think it could be?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message: It is just power cycling. Do I need to repeat the usual offenders?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message:
Yes I checked all of the usual and everything looks and measured fine. I even went ahead and replaced the clock chipU1900 but that didn't do anything.
Eventually I ended up noticing that L7630 didn't look too well so I removed it and plugged the charger in.
Now I get 3.3v on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, and 5v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>.
There was no voltage on Vcore and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> was around 0.06v which I assume is because L7630 ties to the 1v05 rail.
For some reason though when I put another L7630 from a donor(tried from 2 different boards) it goes back to the usual power cycling.

Diode mode of the pads when L7630 removed from board is around 0.13v on Pin 1 and 0.16v on Pin 2
Voltage mode of the pads is 0.08v on Pin 1 and 0.19 on Pin 2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message: It is power cycling, the question is is CPU Vcore pulsing too? See if you can even measure the other rails pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message:
With L7630 removed from the board all the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> rails, <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> rails are present but no Vcore.
I put L7630 on the board and I got a pulse of around 1v on CPU VCORE, <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> pulses
For some reason <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> pulses quickly at 3.3v then stays around 2.5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message: Could be absolutely anything. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> inspected? <SIGNAL>PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> pulsing too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message:
Yes. <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR> pulsed as high as 2.1v and Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR>(<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>) is a stable 2.5v while <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> is only at 0.4v which I don't know how that could be because I thought the S0 rail will come on when S3 is high.

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> looks great and liquid was never in that area. Most of the liquid damage was from the SMC down to the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> area and I replaced the components in those areas that looked damaged.

How could it be that it doesn't power cycle once I remove L7630 from the board but it does when I put another one on there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> will never come high and there will never be and CPU Vcore if you remove L7630. You create a totally different condition.

I have no idea besides to tell you that there must be a corroded resistor or trace somewhere. SMC replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> issues
threads.message: I haven't replaced the SMC but I'll check around for any damaged resistors.
